prompt.p: A 34-year-old man presents with a history of palpitations, pallor and sweating. He also describes headaches and intermittent bouts of anxiety. Although his blood pressure is normal in clinic, you note it has previously been 178/95 mmHg and 158/101 mmHg.
What investigation would you request to obtain a definitive diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option A is Correct. This is the ideal investigation to confirm a high level of metadrenalines, secreted in those with a phaeochromocytoma.
Option B is Incorrect. An ECG will not ascertain the cause of the symptoms seen, although it may characterize rhythm abnormalities.
Option C is Incorrect. While an ECHO will characterize heart blood defects, it cannot be used to diagnose a phaeochromocytoma, which is a tumour of the adrenal medulla.

Option D is Incorrect. The underlying diagnosis is phaeochromocytoma. A random plasma cortisol will not detect the metabolites of adrenaline and noradrenaline characteristically associated with a phaeochromocytoma.
Option E is Incorrect. This will not help obtain a diagnosis here.
